abstract.text: A concrete object for managing your view’s text content and generating the text elements necessary for layout.

inlineContent.text: object provides the backing store for a view that contains text. This object stores the text in an attributed string object, and defaults to using an
object. It also maps portions of the text to
objects to organize the text into paragraphs, lists, and other common element types found in text content. During layout, TextKit uses these elements to lay out and render the text in your view.
The standard system views use an
object to manage their text content. When building a custom text view, use this type to store the text for your view.
to lay out your view’s text. When someone inserts new text or edits the existing text, call the
method and use a block to modify the contents of the
property. Wrapping your edits in an edit transaction lets the rest of the text system respond to those changes.
protocol to identify locations within text.
manager provides its own implementation of this protocol to represent locations within its storage object. To get the start and end locations, access the object’s
property and use them to create new location objects. If you provide your own implementation of the
protocol to manage locations in your content, subclass
and implement your own storage object to support those locations.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
An abstract class that defines the interface and a default implementation for managing the text document contents.
Performs an editing transaction and invokes a block upon completion.
A concrete object for managing your view’s text content and generating the text elements necessary for layout.
Returns the text range, if any, in the backing store that required manual adjustment after editing.
An attributed string that contains the contents of the document.
Returns a new attributed string for the text element.
The delegate for the content storage object.
Returns a new text location object based on an existing location and offset you provide.
Returns the number of characters between the specified locations.
Returns the text element corresponding to object’s attributed string.
The optional methods that delegates of content storage objects implement to handle content processing.
An abstract base class that represents the smallest units of text layout such as paragraphs or attachments.
A protocol the text content manager and its concrete subclasses conform to, which defines the interface for interacting with custom content types of a text document.
Describes the starting and ending locations for the document.
The primary class that you use to manage text layout and presentation for custom text displays.
An interface you implement that represents an abstract location inside your document’s content.
The fundamental storage mechanism of TextKit that contains the text managed by the system.
Optional methods that delegates implement to handle editing and transaction processing.
AppKit-specific keys and values for displaying text and managing documents.
A string of text that manages data, layout, and stylistic information for ranges of characters to support rendering.
A mutable string with associated attributes (such as visual style, hyperlinks, or accessibility data) for portions of its text.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
